nodes.bodyText: I would prefer to avoid the term session, what about LoginJWTTokenHandler ?

@KevinVdV : I agree with @abollini  here. The word "session" is not really appropriate here as it's confusing (is this a user session, an HTTP session, a Hibernate Session, or something else?).  I'd prefer we just call this LoginJWTTokenHandler as he suggested.
Similarly, all the new configurations should be jwt.login.* instead of jwt.session.* and similar.
as above, I would prefer to avoid the term session as it can be confusing for developers

@abollini This is handled in the following test:

atmire@27e733c#diff-4906e304a90a1dcbf301b3896d39a353R848

This test goes through the following steps to verify the settings:

It sets the expiration of the token to 1ms on the configurationService
The code waits for 2ms
A login is tried with the previously retrieved token
Verified this feedback has been addressed as well

@abollini The following test verifies the short lived token validity:

atmire@27e733c#diff-4906e304a90a1dcbf301b3896d39a353R823

It goes through the following steps:

A private bitstream is created
It creates a user that does not have any particular permissions
The token for that user is retrieved and passed through to the bitstreams retrieval call
The verification that the call is forbidden is done
Verified this feedback looks to be resolved
